docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Mark Nielsen campaigns, he often introduces himself as the Republican running for John G. Rowland's old Congressional seat. No matter that Mr. Rowland, now the Governor, hasn't been in Congress since 1990, and that there have been two Congressmen in the seat since then. Mr. Nielsen, who calls himself a ''John Rowland Republican,'' is the challenger in a competitive race for Fifth District Congressman. He is blunt about seeking to benefit from any coattails the popular governor might offer and any association with Mr. Rowland that would entice voters to cast ballots for him, instead of for the Democratic incumbent James H. Maloney.

headline.main: Coattails And More In the Races For Congress

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'VE never seen a less promising crew,'' said the captain. Nobody disagreed. Several dozen ill-assorted mariners, many of us well past our prime, were slouching on the main deck of the Rose while the captain addressed us from the eminence of his quarterdeck. We had signed on for a day of voluntary bondage on this splendid tall ship, and many of us were having second thoughts. I've been reading sea stories since boyhood. But many trips on the Port Jefferson ferry have never produced quite the same sense of danger and romance. When the chance came to sail from Port Jefferson on the Rose, I jumped at it. And so did many others, which is how we came to be standing here on a chilly October morning, anxiously wondering what our duties would be.
docs.abstract: David Bouchier column describes his recent stint as crew member aboard tallship Rose from Port Jefferson, Long Island; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS America awakened from a recession in 1991, the economy had a lot of work to do. A real estate collapse had left banks in terrible shape. Companies had stopped hiring. The Federal budget deficit had once again started to swell. Incomes had stopped rising for most Americans. Wage inequality had become a national sore. Health insurance was protecting fewer people. Layoffs were spreading to white-collar workers. And as the preliminaries got under way for the 1992 Presidential election, Republicans and Democrats alike promised rapid economic growth that would lift all boats and, in doing so, sweep away these problems.
docs.abstract: Louis Uchitelle assesses performance of US economy since 1991 recession; massive economic expansion took place but has slowed because of global financial crisis; expansion of 1990's is weakest since World War II and worker productivity has not kept pace; most household incomes, adjusted for inflation, are no higher than in 1989; drawings; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Social Security benefits will rise 1.3 percent next year, the Government announced today. That is the smallest cost-of-living increase since 1987. More than 44 million Americans receive such benefits. While most are elderly, about 30 percent are under the age of 65.

headline.main: Citing Low Inflation, Government Makes Only Small Increase in Social Security

docs.abstract: Govt announces that Social Security benefits will rise 1.3 percent next year, smallest cost-of-living increase since 1987; more than 44 million Americans receive such benefits; while most are elderly, about 30 percent are under age of 65; increase is small because inflation, as measured by Consumer Price Index, has been exceptionally low (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The civility of the Connecticut governor's race, in which even the television commercials have been tame, evaporated tonight as Gov. John G. Rowland and his Democratic challenger, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, scrapped during a debate over issues as large as the state's school system and as trivial as how they should refer to each other. The sharpest exchange came over Mrs. Kennelly's plan to cut property taxes by 10 percent, which she said she would accomplish by refunding that amount to towns, which collect the tax. Mr. Rowland, a Republican, derided her plan as a shell game that would drive up state spending.

headline.main: Decorum Is Not on Agenda At Gubernatorial Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton and Congress reached agreement today on the final portion of the nation's $1.7-trillion budget, the first in three decades brought forth with a surplus and one that offers the biggest peacetime increase in military spending since Ronald Reagan was President in 1985. Both sides quickly claimed victory, and complimented each other, on a compromise hammered out 19 days before Election Day that avoided a confrontational Government shutdown. Aides are to translate the agreement into legislative language overnight and both houses are expected to pass it on Friday, when many lawmakers dash home to campaign.

headline.main: BUDGET ACCORD IS REACHED; BOTH SIDES CLAIM A VICTORY AS A SHUTDOWN IS AVERTED

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Republican-led Congress reach agreement on final portion of nation's $1.7-trillion budget, first in three decades to show surplus even though it includes biggest military spending increase since 1985; both sides quickly claim credit and compliment each other on pre-Election Day compromise that averts confrontational Government shutdown; $500-billion package and $20-billion 'emergency' purse provide for vast array of activities; key areas include hiring 100,000 elementary schoolteachers over seven years, farm relief and $820-million over and above Clinton's $1.2-billion request for basic medical research at National Institutes of Health; bill has funds for peacekeeping forces in Bosnia, tightening security at embassies and shoring up IMF reserves; also restores $35 million in aid to North Korea in exchange for curbs on its nuclear weapons and provides $200 million for Capitol visitors' center to enhance security; Federal health plans will be required to provide contraceptive coverage, although doctors and some plans with religious objections may exempt themselves; regulation distributing transplant organs on national basis is delayed for year; measures relating to UN dues, family planning and abortion are removed from omnibus bill to avoid veto; Pres Clinton gains major victory in showing his power to influence Congress, despite looming impeachment hearings; Speaker Gingrich recaps Republicans wins in way that essentially cedes dominance to Clinton; photos; boths sides claim to protect surplus; environmentalists grumble about Clinton's concessions on more logging in Alaska, laxer grazing permits and continuation of ozone-depleting pesticides; final package bars District of Columbia from using its own money for needle-exchange program, but drops gay adoption ban and school vouchers; also out are measures to stop doctors from assisting in suicides, to give states all money from Medicaid tobacco settlements, and to bar FDA from evaluating abortion drugs; decision on census sampling is put off (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Coventry Health Care Inc., a managed care company, has agreed to sell its Principal Health Care of Florida unit to Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida for $95 million. Coventry, based in Bethesda, Md., provides health care benefits and services to employers and government-financed groups in six states. With revenue of $1.23 billion last year, it has 1.6 million members in 21 markets in the Midwest, the Mid-Atlantic states and the Southeast. Its stock rose 93.75 cents, to $7.125, in Nasdaq trading. Principal Health Care of Florida has more than 138,000 commercial customers and annual revenue of $225 million.

headline.main: COVENTRY HEALTH WILL SELL FLORIDA UNIT FOR $95 MILLION

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter F. Vallone, the Democratic candidate for governor, yesterday proposed a radical revamping of health care coverage in New York to guarantee that everyone is insured, mainly by making the state, rather than private health insurers, the primary provider of coverage. Under his proposal, individuals could still purchase private insurance but the all employers in the state would be required to participate in the program. Patients could pick their own doctors, and by eliminating much of the role of private insurers, Mr. Vallone said, the state could save $7 billion that now goes to administrative costs and profit margins.

headline.main: Assailing H.M.O.'s, Vallone Offers Broad Plan for State Role in Health Care
